paragraphs.text: It's time to reinvent what universities can be.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: With the annual Ucas university application deadline looming on Thursday, thousands of 17-year-olds will be putting the finishing touches to their personal statements
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And so another cycle of conditional offers, A-level results and nervous forays into freshers' week begins
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Unlike 50 years ago, when a tiny, socially elite proportion went to university
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: they will be joining almost 50% of their peers in studying for a degree, facing average costs of upwards of? 46k for a three-year degree, including tuition and living costs, compared with the generous grants available up until the 1990s
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Setting expansion aside, it is remarkable how much hasn't changed: at the heart of the system remains a core model of young people moving away to university to study for three-year full-time degrees
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: an expensive route
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: for which they now bear much of the costs themselves
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Yet the jobs market has changed beyond recognition
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Graduates are now responsible for forging their own careers in a fluid market compared with the jobs for life that were the norm a few decades ago
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: employers are demanding a completely different set of skills
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Does this model, then, remain fit for purpose?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The political debate has focused on fee levels and headline prices to the exclusion of almost everything else, including the benefits and value of a university education - and how they might be improved
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The debate about whether the 50% participation target is too high has been similarly staid
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: surely it's a no-brainer to hope that at least half of young people engage in advanced learning
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But what type of learning should that be?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: One of the purported benefits of marketising higher education was that the market itself would deliver innovation and better value
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But the government massively overegged the potential for higher education to behave like a market
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Student demand far exceeds supply of places and price has become a proxy for quality
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Little wonder, then, that average fees are far higher than the? 6,000 a year that the then universities minister, David Willetts, predicted
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: when
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: he introduced the? 9,000 fee cap
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We now have the nonsense of a market where students pay the same for very different amounts and quality of academic provision
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This is reflected in the variation in students' own perceptions
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: research by the consumer body Which? found almost a third of first-year undergraduates thought their course was poor value for money
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: while
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: less than half thought seminars were worth attending
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: There is too little accountability for this variation within the powerful sector
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: universities award their own degrees
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: the sector is opaque
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: even resisting moves to publish comparable information on the amount of teaching students can expect for their fees
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the higher education regulator is weak, with virtually no powers to tell universities to buck up standards
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The debate about innovation has centred on distance learning and Moocs (Massive Online Open Courses)
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: There is no doubt developments in technology have the potential to transform the way university education is experienced
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But it's pointless to focus on technology at the expense of changes that need to happen in the system in order to take advantage of it
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Moocs will not transform the sector until they are embraced by the most prestigious universities
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: why shouldn't you be able to study for a cut-price Oxford degree, half via YouTube and Skype, and half among the dreaming spires?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Other innovations that could bring down costs without sacrificing quality might be a restructure of the system to standardise first-year curriculums
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: enabling young people to combine studying for a year or two at their local university with a year or two on campus at a more specialist institution
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We could see more professional degrees co-delivered and funded by universities and employers, such as the accountancy degree offered by Durham and KPMG
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: in which young people benefit from six years of combined university and work experience
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Or there could be more intensive two-year courses, perhaps aimed at young people getting a year or two of work experience after school
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: University could be combined with more modern ways of adjusting to adulthood
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: for example, a year spent in a structured volunteering programme, such as that offered by the charity City Year, offers huge opportunities to develop the grit and teamwork so valued by today's employers
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: while making a real contribution to schools and other public services
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But on some measures we are moving backwards, with a massive fall in numbers of part-time and mature students in the few years since the ? 9,000 fee cap was introduced
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: There are lessons from the 1960s
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: when
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Harold Wilson's government realised that the only way to increase access in the face of a reluctant sector was to back Michael Young's vision for a new institution, the Open University
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: which increased the student population by Britain by a fifth
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: when
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it was launched via its distance learning degrees
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Government can't simply wait for the sector to do what it is asked to do
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It needs to foster a conversation with universities, students and employers about what it means to get a degree
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Of course there will always be a role for the academic
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But should we be shoehorning the majority of undergraduates into this model, or should getting a degree more routinely encompass work experience?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It should also introduce strong new accountabilities within the sector
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: One way of doing this would be to separate degree-awarding powers from learning provision, as suggested by the Social Market Foundation
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This would allow new providers to offer innovative ways of meeting the standards set by a Russell Group university, for example
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And government should provide more incentives for universities to innovate
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Come Friday, many teenagers will be heaving a collective sigh of relief once their applications are in
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: They deserve the best possible learning experience for the significant time and money they will invest in their degrees
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: it's critical we don't shy away from a challenge to universities to ensure their ivory towers continue to evolve to keep pace with the world around them
paragraphs.label: assumption
